...more people to transact in misery than before. The final result of capacity increases, therefore, is to increase the equilibrium transaction rate, which is to increase the sum total of miserable transactions. (3/4)

The Utterly Dismal Theorem of onchain scaling: Any capacity increase can only relieve misery for a while, for as long as misery is the only check on transactions, the improvement will enable the transaction rate to grow, and will soon enable... (2/4)
The Dismal Theorem of onchain scaling: If the only ultimate check on the growth of transactions is misery, then transactions will grow until it is miserable enough to stop their growth. (1/4)

Look for PRs and issues with the Tests label and see if you can help review/test. Good luck, and ping me on IRC if you have questions.

Something else you might want to look at is whether the txs signal opt-in RBF ( https:// github.com/bitcoin/bips/b lob/master/bip-0125.mediawiki … )? Using RBF allows a user to set a lower fee, and then bump the fee if the tx isn't confirmed within their required time window.

Perhaps not everyone can write consensus code, but *everyone* can learn more. All lightning implementations are open source: - https:// github.com/ACINQ/eclair - https:// github.com/ElementsProjec t/lightning … - https:// github.com/lightningnetwo rk/lnd … - https:// github.com/mit-dci/lit Seems transparent to me.
learn; teach; fix; build. Let this be your credo.
Don't waste your time on those who complain that Bitcoin isn't perfect and don't try to make it better themselves. Don't waste it on those who complain that someone else has spoiled Bitcoin for them.
Therefore: don't waste it on those who snipe from the sidelines without understanding the tech. Don't waste it on those who don't *want* to understand.
Things are moving incredibly fast. There aren't enough hours to keep up with everything that's happening. The only thing more scarce than Bitcoin is your time.

Remember: Bitcoin and lightning are open source protocols. If you don't understand them, it's your responsibility to educate yourself; if you think they're broken, it's your responsibility to fix them; if you don't like them, it's your responsibility to build something better.

I made the mistake of feeding this troll last week. I see she's now doubling down on I don't understand the tech but I'll make wild and inaccurate claims about it anyway." Suggested action: a swift mute."

Please, just stop now. Payments in lightning are atomic and can't be stolen. That's what the HTLC construction ensures. If you find lightning so offensive, the solution is simple: don't use it. It's an opt-in, voluntary system, just like bitcoin.

Again, it's not possible to 'hijack' others' funds. Why do you keep repeating that? There's a good introduction here: https:// github.com/lightningnetwo rk/lightning-rfc/blob/master/00-introduction.md … . Happy to answer any questions once you've read through those docs!

That's not how it works. 280 characters isn't enough to explain lightning. There are a lot of good resources out there explaining the technology. I can point you to some of them if you'd like. There are also lots of friendly developers who are happy to help :)

Why do you talk about what 'cannot possibly' be instead of reading the specification or talking to people implementing the technology? You can even download and run the software yourself if you don't want to trust anyone: http:// dev.lightning.community/guides/install ation/ …

He certainly did :) If you don't believe him, you can read the spec for yourself here: https:// github.com/lightningnetwo rk/lightning-rfc/blob/master/04-onion-routing.md#overview … The route is constructed by the origin node, which knows the public keys of each intermediate node...""
Not true. The routing is source-based. The sender choses the path.
Also, the claim that intermediate hops can steal payments reveals a fundamental misunderstanding of the technology and cryptographic constructions. I suggest you read the spec.

It looks to me like the premise of this article the final route is randomly determined" is incorrect. Lightning payments use source-based routing. @izakaminska - I recommend you talk to people who are working on this technology. Lightning implementers are a friendly bunch!"
Thanks! Glad you enjoyed them!
You're welcome!

I would like a hard fork block size increase at some point, if it were safe, consensus-driven and desired by the Bitcoin users. I don't think that decision should be fee-driven. We still have enormous opportunity to increase utility per fee before that block size increase.
Payment channels were implemented in bitcoinj in 2013: https:// github.com/bitcoinj/bitco inj/commit/3d74934b6f057212174ee64a7216266373c93626 …
I'm suggesting that @bitpay reduce costs users today by rolling out better technology. @spair 's preferred way forward (2X) was a plan to instead just externalize those costs onto the network.
SegWit transactions: give immediate fee relief, regardless of network adoption. As far as I'm aware, @bitpay do not use SegWit transactions yet.

Unidirectional payment channels: have been well-understood and deployable for at least 5 years. Steam (small, semi-regular txs to a single recipient) would be a perfect use case. Why hasn't @bitpay started rolling out payment channels?

Appropriate fee estimation: The chairman of @bitpay , @TonyGallippi , showed that he has no understanding of fee estimation and that @bitpay customers are overpaying by orders of magnitude: https:// twitter.com/jfnewbery/stat us/931375233822584832 …

@bitpay just lost a big customer because fees were too high. They have the opportunity to reduce fees for customers today by deploying well understood technology: - appropriate fee estimation - unidirectional payment channels - SegWit transactions
@bitpay drags its feet on segwit and lightning, the market routes around it. As predicted. https:// twitter.com/AlyseKilleen/s tatus/939915592554840065 …

I've been contributing to Bitcoin Core for about a year and I hardly ever touch consensus code. When I do, I write PR comments like this: https:// github.com/bitcoin/bitcoi n/pull/11389#pullrequestreview-69600608 … begging for review and test!

I'm not sure that's the right lesson. I think better lessons are: have humility when touching consensus code; accept that it's difficult and there will be edge cases that you haven't thought of; have as many eyes reviewing it and testing it as possible.
I'm by no means the first person to say this!

Really @jgarzik ? That's what you learned? How about these lessons: 1. Changes to Bitcoin require consensus from the users and can't be dictated by a closed group. 2. No-one should run untested and unreviewed code from a one-man development team. pic.twitter.com/bkhE1SoaEP

Yes, and I think that means that for most miners, if they'd set -blockmaxsize" before the hard fork height as was suggested, then they would have been mining invalid large blocks before the correct height. nBlockMaxSize is completely independent from block height."

You know me and you know I've repeatedly argued against demonising people who supported NYA, even though I've always opposed it myself.

> The reason people like me go on about this distinction is false accusations of malice deepen Balkanization. Good! I agree tribalism is bad. My point is that *I* no longer believe that Jeff is acting with good intent. You conclusion may be different from mine. That's ok.

Not true - NYA proponents repeatedly stated that strong replay protection was not included so SPV clients would follow the 2x chain, and that the intent was to kill the original chain so that there was only one coin.
As far as I'm aware, Adam has never contributed any code to BCash. Ryan, I think you're barking up the wrong tree here.
By the way, it's possible that some of that ad-hoc replay protection relied on block 494,784 being the fork block. If SegWit2x had forked, people could have lost money due to the off-by-one bug.

> much of the work to mitigate disruption is already done No work was done by btc1 to mitigate disruption. That cost was externalized onto businesses and individuals in the Bitcoin community, who had to spend many hours creating ad-hoc replay protection.

Yet he continues to write code for SegWit2x even though the 'upgrade' story isn't possible. There's no consensus. Backers have backed out. If he wants SegWit2x to be an alternative coin, he should include replay protection, etc. However you slice this, it looks bad.

Jeff's stated intention was never to create a new forked coin. He and the other NYA promoters wanted to 'upgrade' Bitcoin and kill the old chain. Hence no replay protection, service bit hiding, no new network magic.

That's not really true. I completely support peoples' right to exit Bitcoin and create a fork. If they want to do that using a UTXO snapshot, then they have a responsibility to minimize disruption to the original chain.
Forking now, when it's clear that SegWit2x does not have consensus, would simply cause disruption for Bitcoin. That's why I no longer believe that Jeff is acting with good intent.

Yes - he's telling people to run the patches, which would cause a hard fork. Remember - SegWit2x can only succeed by becoming the one true chain. See https:// github.com/btc1/bitcoin/i ssues/99#issuecomment-320450248 … for example. That's why there's no replay protection.

Why is Jeff writing code *today* to create a hard fork and telling people to run it? He and 5 other NYA signers announced SegWit2x was dead last week. It clearly does not have consensus. The only thing running the forking code can do now is cause disruption.
what if I don't want to?
In case it's not clear: no-one should run btc1 code. It is untested, unreviewed, buggy and can only serve to disrupt and confuse the Bitcoin network.
There are more bugs in the btc1 code. I can't in good conscience reveal what those are, since I have no intention of helping create a disruptive hard fork.
Trying to create a SegWit2x fork at this point, when it's clear that it doesn't have consensus, is simply sowing discord and confusion.
In case it's not clear: SegWit2x only makes sense if it has consensus and can bring the network with it. That's what we were told again and again: 2x is an upgrade and will become the one true chain.
When I pointed this out to Jeff, he immediately created a patch and pushed it out.

This is a simple bug. Any reasonably competent coder would have spotted this (not least because a compiler or static analysis could have warned that a member was being accessed before initialization). Any reasonable review process would have caught this. Sadly btc1 had neither.

I then took a look at the miner activation code. There's another bug there. In the BlockAssembler constructor code, fWitnessSeasoned is being accessed before initialization. The result: no large block can be mined to trigger the fork.

Looking at the code, it appears that Jeff made an off-by-one error. That's not entirely surprising. The VersionBitsState() code is confusing, and the commit where Jeff added the hard fork code had no review: https:// github.com/btc1/bitcoin/p ull/50 … .

Block 494,784 was announced an discussed as the forking block many times over the last few months. Here https:// twitter.com/jgarzik/status /888270313502330880 … and here https:// segwit2x.github.io/segwit2x-annou nce.html … and here https:// lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitc oin-segwit2x/2017-October/000520.html … for example.

Segwit2x was announced abandoned last week, but there are still some residual nodes in the network. This morning, those nodes froze at block 494,782. That's two blocks before the intended hard fork at 494,784.
I try to assume good intentions in people. Unfortunately, I can no longer do so for @jgarzik . My judgement is that he is acting to disrupt the bitcoin network to advance his own interests.
I'm not blaming the users. Executives of Bitcoin services companies have a duty to minimize fees for users. If they don't, their customers should complain, or take their business elsewhere!

Tony, the median feerate for the previous 3 blocks (494722-494724) was 22 sat/vbyte, giving a fee of under 5,000 satoshis for a standard transaction. Your fee is 20x too high. Are BitPay customers really wasting tens of thousands of dollars on unnecessary fees every day? https:// twitter.com/TonyGallippi/s tatus/931370995176345601 …
I have enormous gratitude and respect for the project maintainers. The job requires patience, wisdom, experience and judgement. All our maintainers do a fantastic job.
Great! We're in total agreement. Can we stop using the mean when describing fees in bitcoin?

Absolutely correct! The context for this tweet perhaps isn't clear. Several prominent people have been trying to argue using mean fee for a single block. I hope this illustrates how misleading that measure is.
Used a small sample size and an inappropriate measure to produce a misleading statistic.
Average fees on Bitcoin Cash are currently $44.30! https:// blockchair.com/bitcoin-cash/b lock/503738 … @ErikVoorhees @mikebelshe
People who quote mean transaction fee either don't understand the technology or are pushing an agenda using misleading stats.
Many reasons, but see my reply on the other fork of this bifurcated thread for some solid, valid objections to 2x!

Difficult to condense complex argument to 280 chars. Core contributors are individuals and have own views, but I think @morcos does a good job of summarising valid objections to 2x in his medium posts: https:// medium.com/@morcos

@BrennanGeis - exactly what Jorge said. Also, there's not really a single agenda or plan. Bitcoin change happens by some kind of social consensus - the base block size is a consensus rule and so any changes to it would need to gather social consensus first.

We've released the most robust and performant Bitcoin client yet: https:// bitcoincore.org/en/releases/0. 15.0.1/ … (thanks to @orionwl and all contributors!)

Bitcoin is an opt-in, voluntary system. The user sets the fees, the fees don't happen to the user.

The wording here is slightly wrong, but result is correct. Should be 100k vsize.
Businesses have no incentive to improve their fee estimation if users don't exercise voice/exit.
I suggest you take your complaint to coinbase, or take your business elsewhere. It's money out of your pocket!
That gave you a radically different result than if you'd just chosen a block at random.
Oh, one other thing I noticed. The block you chose had the *2nd highest* mean fee for all blocks in that 144 block window.
The blockchain is a precious and scarce resource. Let's use it that way.
Point being, a single number doesn't capture the opportunities for scale and efficiency that are available to us today.
Again, depending on spending patterns, that could save you 10x, 100x, 1000x.
A bit more radical, but absolutely possible with today's available tech would be to use channels for recurrent transactions.
What are we down to now? Around 5 cents?
( @hrdng wrote a great article about that here: https:// bitcointechtalk.com/saving-up-to-8 0-on-bitcoin-transaction-fees-by-batching-payments-4147ab7009fb … .)
Let's take it a step further. If you're prepared to batch your transactions in groups of 3-4, you could easily save up to 3x.
You have access to these savings *today*, simply by using segwit and being prepared to wait a bit for your transaction.
With that weight and a feerate of 10 sat/vB, the tx fee is $0.15. That's almost unfairly cheap!
If we use a segwit input instead of non-segwit, the vsize have been lower - probably 208 instead of 226 for this simple transaction.
Let's try to do better. There's an opt-in, voluntary way to access scale on Bitcoin - segwit.
If you'd sent your transaction with that feerate, you'd have been confirmed for a cost of $0.16.
Block 493114 for example cleared out the mempool down to sub 10 sat/vB transactions: https:// blockchain.info/block/00000000 00000000002234fe6347a4f02f926b3a12dc604c50524928ffc0799b … .
If you were willing to wait that long, your transaction would have been confirmed with very low fees.
Often, it's fine to wait 24 hours for your transaction to be confirmed. If your primary concern is fees, you can save a lot this way.
Doing that gives us a feerate of 191 sat/byte, so an implied fee of $3.10.
That gives us a good measure of what fee rate would be required to get in one of those blocks.
We should look for the minimum of the 80th centiles for the block and the 5 subsequent blocks.
But you probably don't want to optimize to include your transaction in the next block. If you can wait an hour, you'll get have lower fees.
80th centile feerate is 260 sat/byte, so $4.22.
... and it had this feerate, 20% of the transactions in the block would have a lower feerate. Your tx would almost certainly get included.)
(why 80th centile? Because it means that if your transaction was in the mempool when this block was mined ...
Of course, that single transaction could be out-of-band, or a stingy-parent-generous-child. Let's take the 80th centile feerate to be sure.

Lowest feerate transaction in your block was https:// blockchain.info/tx/bdf2a264545 ecac76343358a9f193fc062fc5db8461ac2b6dc6b5f840914ae37 … , 101 sat/byte - which would be $1.63 for an average sized tx.
(No-one wins a prize for being the highest paying tx in a block. It's just additional miner surplus)
But really, you want your transaction to have the *lowest* fee-rate of all txs in the block. That maximizes your consumer surplus.
Doing that gives us a feerate of 264 sat/vB and vsize 226 . At $7176, the fee is $4.31. Ok, that's still pretty high.
A better average would be median feerate multiplied by median transaction vsize.
[that tx weighed 40vkB. It excluded everyone else on earth from using our most secure ledger for a whole minute for just $1800. Cheap!]
Your block had 1881 transactions. That means that tx 745879e... alone contributed about $1 to the 'average' fee.
That tx was almost 100k and paid $1876 in fees. Outliers like that affect the mean disproportionately.
Firstly, mean tx fee is a really useless measure. For example, your block contains this tx: https:// blockchain.info/tx/745879e0481 6c2244bba3453004fc2d5b7a5d92c86f0e037d49cc822b2ed202c … .

... delete Jonas's and Nicolas's hardware wallet integration work, so your private keys will always be in your hot wallet...
... back out Matt's multithreading and scheduling refactors, so your node is mostly limited to running a single process ...
... erase Alex's fee estimation improvements so you pay too much for your transactions...
... get rid of Russ's process separation groundwork, so your signing code will be in the same memory space as your network code ...
... throw out Greg's signature aggregation research so your blocks will contain fewer transactions and take 2-4x longer to validate ...
... undo Cory's net refactor so your transactions and blocks take longer to propagate across the network ...
... revert Luke's multiwallet so you can only access a single wallet on your node ...
... remove Suhas's pruning code, so you need to store tens of GBs of dead data if you want to run a full node ...
... switch back from Pieter's libsecp256k1 to OpenSSL, so your transaction signing/validation is 5x slower and less secure ...
